manuscriptsList.title: Martianus Capella, De nuptiis and other texts
manuscriptsList.contents: Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis Philologiae et Mercurii and some other short texts.

folioParts.fpdescription: The other scribe added a note on musical pitches, and two sets of schemes regarding syllogistic propositions.
A line separates the sets of examples of syllogisms.
We know who one of these scribes was – Rather of Verona (890-974) added a copy of a letter at the base of the page.

For example, using a ‘mixed’ syllogism: ‘Whether the knowledge of discussing is useful. If good discussion is useful, the science of discussing well is useful. But good discussion is useful... Therefore dialectic is useful.’
(5) scheme
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 30v.
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 30v.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 31r: example of a very full commentary added in the margin. The book is 307 mm high.

folioParts.fpdescription: In the second set of schemes lines connect terms of the propositions and conclusion in order to indicate how the argument is constructed. Visualising the argument in this way helps understand why it is valid.
The scheme is evidence of a reader trying to understand the steps made by Dialectic in reaching this conclusion; the scheme illustrates the reader’s thought process!

folioParts.fpdescription: Schemes

Text in the box: ‘According to Calcidius, entelechy is perfecta aetas, completed lifetime. According to Aristotle, it is interpreted as absolute perfection. Plato, on the other hand, says that entelechy is the anima mundi, the soul of the world.’
Leiden UB BPL 88 f.2r

Categoriae Aristotelis, ab Augustino de graeco in latinum mutatae (f.24r). Notes et fragments, parmi lesquels une note sur le sens du mot Cerauna (f.39r), des tables de comput (f.41r), dont l'une faite en 896 par frater Johannis Scotti Aldelmus (f.42r), des règles sur la grosseur des tuyaux sonores (f.43r). folios.foliodescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 27 bis r

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 1r. Opening of Aristotle’s Peri Hermeneias (On Interpretation) in the translation of Boethius. You may recognize this page from the teaser of this exhibition. Aristotle’s On Interpretation deals with the relationship between words, reality and logic.

folioParts.fpdescription: At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’
Introduction (accessus) to the author, Augustine, and an etymology of the word dialectica, with a reference to John Scot Eriugenia.
Opening of De dialectica, with the well-known opening words: “Dialectia est bene disputandi scientia”; “Dialectic is the art of arguing well.
‘Heiricus magister Remigii fecit has glossas’

folioParts.fpdescription: ‘We should not accept this gloss’ - ‘Non est haec glossa a nobis recipienda.’

folioParts.fpdescription: In close-up, the dirt and wear and tear on the page are even more visible. We can also see that a later hand wrote the title of the work on the top of the page: ‘Aristotelis liber i peri er[meneias] a boecio comentatus expositusque’ (see green box) (The first book of Aritotle’s Peri hermeneias, commented upon and expounded by Boethius). In the red box you can see the Greek title of Aristotle’s work, Peri Hermeneias. It is written in Greek capitals. A line over the words emphasizes the fact that it is Greek.

manuscriptsList.title: Boethius, Isagoge
manuscriptsList.contents: Boethius, Isagoge

folios.foliodescription: Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315 (605), p. 139: representation of Porphyry’s five predicables

folioParts.fpdescription: The text has been carefully corrected, here ‘ad’ has been corrected to ‘ab’ and ‘actenus’ to ‘hactenus’.
Here small squiggles have been added in the margin alongside the text; these are rudimentary quotation marks indicating original text from the Isagoge, the subject of Boethius’ commentary.

Here interlinear glosses have been added to provide Latin equivalents of the Greek terms hyperbaton (transposition of words) and zeuma (where one word can be used in two different contexts). The glossator describes these as ‘confusus ordo’, the confusion of order, and ‘repetitio’, repetition, respectively.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8v: INCIPIT ARS DIALECTICA ALCHOINI PHILOSOPHI. AD KAROLUM MAGNUM
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 63r: List of propositions

folioParts.fpdescription: The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’.

Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition.

Ch: How many species are there in dialectic? A: The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is …

Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …

A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84: On f. 8v we find the quire signature ‘c’, suggesting that this gathering of leaves was once the third in a collection.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 1r: The opening of Cicero’s De inventione

folioParts.fpdescription: Here the glossator introduces the characters in the conversation.
‘Ecce’, ‘Look’, the glossator writes – ‘an example of induction’ .

The glossator indicates who is speaking between the lines (‘Aspasia’s words’, ’Xenophon’s wife responds’ etc). These names and  characters may have been unfamiliar to the reader, so these cues helped them follow the text.
These schemata (f. 11r) summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case.
On f. 58v, a glossator adds Augustine’s list of the eight categories of lies (De mendacio, 25).

manuscriptsList.title: De consolatione philosophiae and other text(s)
manuscriptsList.contents: This manuscript contains Boethius’ Consolation of Philosophy (f. 2r-52r), and the first two books of Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis Philosophiae et Mercurii (f. 53r-93r). F. 94 is an unrelated fragment from Macrobius’ In somnium Scipionis, dated to ca. 1100 (Gumbert, IIMM).The texts in this codex are not core texts for the arts of rhetoric and dialectic, but they illustrate these arts in practice: both authors present rich stories in a mix of prose and poetry, engaging with many of the principles of rhetoric and dialectic in their text. In the Consolation of Philosophy, lady Philosophy argues with the author, who has fallen on bad times, about the value and meaning of life. In Martianus’ De nuptiis, the story of Mercury’s marriage with Lady Philology shows how all the liberal arts contribute to an ultimate knowing of the universe.
manuscriptsList.codicologicalUnits: Composite Manuscript made up of two parts (ff. 1-93v, f.94)

folios.foliodescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 69r: a column for commentary on the left of the tekst, and two columns on the right. The lower margin is also typically large to house large amounts of notes and comments

folioParts.fpdescription: A close up shows how equisite and detailed the penwork is. The size of the initial signifies the structure of the text: the larger the initial, the more important the unit of text is it opens. Red and blue are the usual colours of ink to use for these initials and the penwork, often in alternation.

In the red triangle we read: “in voce earum quae sunt”. This is a correction for a passage in the main text, which originally read “que sunt in voce”. In the main tekst, the passage is marked with dots under the letters, signifying that these words should be deleted and replaced by the correction in het margin.
A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy.

In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations.

allPages.title: The medieval classroom
allPages.summary: Books used in the classroom are witnesses to medieval processes of teaching and learning.

allPages.title: The curriculum
allPages.summary: In class students studied seven liberal arts, those related to language (grammar, rhetoric, and logic) and those related to the sciences (arithmetic, geometry, music, and astronomy).

allPages.title: Rhetoric and dialectic
allPages.summary: The disciplines of rhetoric and dialectic were crucial to the art of reasoning.

folios.foliodescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 27 bis r

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 1r. Opening of Aristotle’s Peri Hermeneias (On Interpretation) in the translation of Boethius. You may recognize this page from the teaser of this exhibition. Aristotle’s On Interpretation deals with the relationship between words, reality and logic.

folioParts.fpdescription: At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’

We can also see that a later hand wrote the title of the work on the top of the page: ‘Aristotelis liber i peri er[meneias] a boecio comentatus expositusque’ (see green box) (The first book of Aritotle’s Peri hermeneias, commented upon and expounded by Boethius). In the red box you can see the Greek title of Aristotle’s work, Peri Hermeneias. It is written in Greek capitals. A line over the words emphasizes the fact that it is Greek.

folioParts.fpdescription: The text has been carefully corrected, here ‘ad’ has been corrected to ‘ab’ and ‘actenus’ to ‘hactenus’.
Here small squiggles have been added in the margin alongside the text; these are rudimentary quotation marks indicating original text from the Isagoge, the subject of Boethius’ commentary.

Here interlinear glosses have been added to provide Latin equivalents of the Greek terms hyperbaton (transposition of words) and zeuma (where one word can be used in two different contexts). The glossator describes these as ‘confusus ordo’, the confusion of order, and ‘repetitio’, repetition, respectively.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8v: INCIPIT ARS DIALECTICA ALCHOINI PHILOSOPHI. AD KAROLUM MAGNUM
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 63r: List of propositions

folioParts.fpdescription: The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’.

Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition.

Ch: How many species are there in dialectic? A: The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is …

Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …

A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84: On f. 8v we find the quire signature ‘c’, suggesting that this gathering of leaves was once the third in a collection.

folioParts.fpdescription: Here the glossator introduces the characters in the conversation.
‘Ecce’, ‘Look’, the glossator writes – ‘an example of induction’ .

The glossator indicates who is speaking between the lines (‘Aspasia’s words’, ’Xenophon’s wife responds’ etc). These names and  characters may have been unfamiliar to the reader, so these cues helped them follow the text.
These schemata (f. 11r) summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case.
On f. 58v, a glossator adds Augustine’s list of the eight categories of lies (De mendacio, 25).

manuscriptsList.title: De consolatione philosophiae and other text(s)
manuscriptsList.contents: This manuscript contains Boethius’ Consolation of Philosophy (f. 2r-52r), and the first two books of Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis Philosophiae et Mercurii (f. 53r-93r). F. 94 is an unrelated fragment from Macrobius’ In somnium Scipionis, dated to ca. 1100 (Gumbert, IIMM).The texts in this codex are not core texts for the arts of rhetoric and dialectic, but they illustrate these arts in practice: both authors present rich stories in a mix of prose and poetry, engaging with many of the principles of rhetoric and dialectic in their text. In the Consolation of Philosophy, lady Philosophy argues with the author, who has fallen on bad times, about the value and meaning of life. In Martianus’ De nuptiis, the story of Mercury’s marriage with Lady Philology shows how all the liberal arts contribute to an ultimate knowing of the universe.
manuscriptsList.codicologicalUnits: Composite Manuscript made up of two parts (ff. 1-93v, f.94)

folios.foliodescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 69r: a column for commentary on the left of the tekst, and two columns on the right. The lower margin is also typically large to house large amounts of notes and comments

folioParts.fpdescription: A close up shows how equisite and detailed the penwork is. The size of the initial signifies the structure of the text: the larger the initial, the more important the unit of text is it opens. Red and blue are the usual colours of ink to use for these initials and the penwork, often in alternation.

In the red triangle we read: “in voce earum quae sunt”. This is a correction for a passage in the main text, which originally read “que sunt in voce”. In the main tekst, the passage is marked with dots under the letters, signifying that these words should be deleted and replaced by the correction in het margin.
A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy.

In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations.
a
b
Grid on f.4v

title: Martianus Capella, De nuptiis and other texts
contents: Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis Philologiae et Mercurii and some other short texts.

folioParts.fpdescription: The other scribe added a note on musical pitches, and two sets of schemes regarding syllogistic propositions.
A line separates the sets of examples of syllogisms.
We know who one of these scribes was – Rather of Verona (890-974) added a copy of a letter at the base of the page.

For example, using a ‘mixed’ syllogism: ‘Whether the knowledge of discussing is useful. If good discussion is useful, the science of discussing well is useful. But good discussion is useful... Therefore dialectic is useful.’
(5) scheme
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 30v.
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 30v.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 31r: example of a very full commentary added in the margin. The book is 307 mm high.

folioParts.fpdescription: In the second set of schemes lines connect terms of the propositions and conclusion in order to indicate how the argument is constructed. Visualising the argument in this way helps understand why it is valid.
The scheme is evidence of a reader trying to understand the steps made by Dialectic in reaching this conclusion; the scheme illustrates the reader’s thought process!

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8v: INCIPIT ARS DIALECTICA ALCHOINI PHILOSOPHI. AD KAROLUM MAGNUM
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 63r: List of propositions

folioParts.fpdescription: The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’.

Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition.

Ch: How many species are there in dialectic? A: The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is …

Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …

A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84: On f. 8v we find the quire signature ‘c’, suggesting that this gathering of leaves was once the third in a collection.

title: De inventione and other text(s)
contents: De inventione / Cicero (f.1r-50v), Letter to Aristotle / pseudo-Alexander the Great (f.50v-58v), Rhetorica ad Herennium / pseudo-Cicero (f.59r-112v)

folioParts.fpdescription: These schemata (f. 11r) summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case.

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 1r: The opening of Cicero’s De inventione

folioParts.fpdescription: Here the glossator introduces the characters in the conversation.
‘Ecce’, ‘Look’, the glossator writes – ‘an example of induction’ .

The glossator indicates who is speaking between the lines (‘Aspasia’s words’, ’Xenophon’s wife responds’ etc). These names and  characters may have been unfamiliar to the reader, so these cues helped them follow the text.
These schemata (f. 11r) summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case.
On f. 58v, a glossator adds Augustine’s list of the eight categories of lies (De mendacio, 25).

folios.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 105r. Manuscript made in the twelfth century.

title: Cicero’s De inventione and other texts
contents: Cicero, De inventione (ff. 1-46r), Boethius, De differentiis topicis, IV (ff. 46r-52v), Pseudo-Cicero, Rhetorica ad Herennium (ff. 52v-102r)

title: De consolatione philosophiae and other text(s)
contents: This manuscript contains Boethius’ Consolation of Philosophy (f. 2r-52r), and the first two books of Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis Philosophiae et Mercurii (f. 53r-93r). F. 94 is an unrelated fragment from Macrobius’ In somnium Scipionis, dated to ca. 1100 (Gumbert, IIMM).The texts in this codex are not core texts for the arts of rhetoric and dialectic, but they illustrate these arts in practice: both authors present rich stories in a mix of prose and poetry, engaging with many of the principles of rhetoric and dialectic in their text. In the Consolation of Philosophy, lady Philosophy argues with the author, who has fallen on bad times, about the value and meaning of life. In Martianus’ De nuptiis, the story of Mercury’s marriage with Lady Philology shows how all the liberal arts contribute to an ultimate knowing of the universe.
codicologicalUnits: Composite Manuscript made up of two parts (ff. 1-93v, f.94)

folios.foliodescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 69r: a column for commentary on the left of the tekst, and two columns on the right. The lower margin is also typically large to house large amounts of notes and comments

folioParts.fpdescription: A close up shows how equisite and detailed the penwork is. The size of the initial signifies the structure of the text: the larger the initial, the more important the unit of text is it opens. Red and blue are the usual colours of ink to use for these initials and the penwork, often in alternation.

In the red triangle we read: “in voce earum quae sunt”. This is a correction for a passage in the main text, which originally read “que sunt in voce”. In the main tekst, the passage is marked with dots under the letters, signifying that these words should be deleted and replaced by the correction in het margin.
A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy.

In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations.
